Comment: Lets go back in time, most employers offered pensions, 401K is the corresponding IRS Tax code, it invented by a GOP Congressman as a tax shelter for executives, the 1% before there was a 1%. Basically it was offered to executives as a perk so they could shelter money back when they actually had to pay 50% under Reagan. As time went by the demand or request to have this option trickled down the corporate ladder. Eventually Corporations light went on, we can dump out pension and throw a match at our workers and maximize profit. None of these were ever intended to be your sole source of retirement income. Time magazine did a front page story on it a few years back titled " Time to dump the 401K.  Many of the retiree's who were the first batch to retire on them were not broke and back to work. Put simply you cannot save enough in todays dollars for tomorrows expenses.

Comment: Apparently I am an exception to the general applause for the new site.  It is too splashy and has too much empty space. Comment: My experience of Mass is that it is human imperfection, leaning as well as it is able in the direction of divine perfection. But in all cases that essential leaning-towards is present, and is beautiful.

Comment: I'll take a stab at why this isn't happening anytime soon: the architects promised VERY FORCEFULLY an extremely high-efficiency building: the promised energy savings were a major selling point for the tiny and hideously expensive proposal. But, since the plans show a Jaqua-like glass box (word has it that the heating/cooling bills for that unimaginative cube hit stratospheric levels…), the promises cannot be fulfilled: glass that is efficient (far from that of a well-insulated wall, however) would consume the budget of a Croesus. 
So, the only available solution is to go WAY over budget (and it's already been upped a couple of million) or seriously downsize the facility. 
Responsible citizens, of course, could demand the Mayor and Manager appear in a public forum and answer questions about this massive project that appears seriously to be going off the rails. But we all know this ain't a gonna happen. 
Heck, even if it did, our "democratic" officials would just ignore us, in the end.

Comment: Here's a little secret:  Regulatory agencies don't have the time or money to do these studies.  Therefore, the agencies require the petitioner to pay for and perform the work.  The ultimate approval is, however, the regulatory agency.  The regulatory agencies approve the experimental plan, review the data collection, participate in the data analysis, and so on. The regulatory agencies are involved every step of the way.  So, having a study "funded by the company" is not as nefarious as it sounds.

Comment: I cannot recall when I have last read such a well articulated statement of passivity and inefficacy.  I cannot help but think of the words of Frederick Douglass.

"If there is no struggle, there is no progress. Those who profess to
favor freedom, and yet depreciate agitation, are men who want crops
without plowing up the ground. They want rain without thunder and
lighting.  They want the ocean without the awful roar of its many waters.
This struggle may be a moral one; or it may be a physical one; or it may
be both moral and physical; but it must be a struggle. Power concedes
nothing without a demand. It never did and it never will. Find out just
what people will submit to, and you have found the exact amount of
injustice and wrong which will be imposed upon them; and these will
continue until they are resisted with either words or blows, or with
both. The limits of tyrants are prescribed by the endurance of those
whom they oppress."

Comment: You didn't take physics in high school, did you?

First, standing on a spinning orb wouldn't result in any force that would "fling" you anywhere. You'd tend to travel in a straight line. You'd need a force (directed toward the center of the spinning orb) holding you on the surface of the orb. That's called centripetal force. (Centripetal means "to seek the center"). Gravity supplies this centripetal force.

Second, centripetal force is calculated by:
(m x v^2) / r

Presuming:
Mass of human = 80kg
Velocity = 1000 MPH (447 m/s)
Radius of Earth = 6,378,137 m (at equator)

The centripetal force needed to keep a human from being "flung into outer space" is 2.5 N (newtons).

The gravitational force between an 80kg human and the Earth, presuming:
* Radius of Earth = 6,378,137 m
* Mass of Earth = 5.972 × 10^24 kg
is 784 N.

The 784 N provided by gravity is way more than the 2.5 N required to keep you from being "flung off the planet".

Comment: Recycling has been pushed by a handful of do gooders for years in Anchorage .  The reason it doesn't make sense in Anchorage is because we are too far from plants that can convert the stuff back into something useful. The cost to ship the stuff to the lower 48 is too expensive .   Unlike locations in the lower 48 states , we have unlimited landfill space .  As a community we do more harm than good recycling . Instead of one truck picking up neighborhoods polluting our air we have to use two trucks going down the same street--one for regular refuse and the other for recycling material .  Why on earth would anyone want to pay twice as much for refuse service when they don't have to ?  SWS customers got shafted because Muni code says they must pay refuse service whether they use it or not. In a mix of smoke and mirrors they tricked customers into thinking they were getting free recycling by juggling the rates . Recycling in Alaska is a waste of time and money and pollutes our air .

Comment: Simple real-world observations will tell you that the number of people long-term making minimum wage is exceedingly small. Most of us got hired at minimum, earned a bump by demonstrating we could follow orders after a few weeks, then another by sticking around and being better than the inexperienced kid who walked into the door.

Anyone stuck at minimum after six months either isn’t cutting it or has demonstrated no initiative to learn new skills, improve the ones we had or had some other performance deficiency.

Arbitrarily assigning a wage based on some notion that X dollars and not a penny less is sufficient to function in society is hardly a basis for sound economics. Who exactly determined the “appropriate” wages for various jobs?

Bottom line: Employment is not some program to improve lives. It’s a mutually agreed upon exchange of labor for remuneration, built on the supply of labor and jobs, the demand for both, and the value-added a worker provides.

Comment: This was well written, and I agree that the intrinsically slimey issue of income splitting should be off the table immediately.

However, with regards to passive income investment, I would ask this:
How are doctors any different than nurses, paramedics, firefighters, or teachers?
If were truly to discuss tax fairness, then the issue of taxpayers money contributing to pensions at all would be on the table. A nurse is guaranteed 60% of her income at retirement, protected against inflation, in exchange for 6% of her salary today. Can you imagine the outcry if we suggested not only taxing that 6% of income, but also the yearly investment gains they must make? In practice, saving within a corporation is simply allowing physicians the same privilege of saving today for a more comfortable tomorrow.

I would also point out that the 6% yearly contribution to a nurses pension approximates the 5% of physician salaries that the MOHLTC helps itself to every year.

Comment: We don't need equal pay for all but we do need to reduce the enormous inequality we now have. According to what I've read, the income and wealth inequality was last at this level right before the Depression. It's bad for individuals and it's bad for the country.

Speaking as someone who has always been either working-class or poor -- I think of poor as just the lowest level of working-class -- the main problem is not our income level but insecurity. We need more secure jobs, where we're not constantly in danger of being laid off or having our hours cut, and they have to pay at least enough to get by on. 

Or we need government programs that make up for the insecurity. The inadequate programs we do have, such as food stamps, subsidize corporations such as Walmart which pay their workers too little and don't provide enough working hours.

See: Hand to Mouth: Living in Bootstrap America" by Linda Tirado. Amazon has it. She describes reality.

Comment: Sorry, "anything can happen" was not meant to be taken literally. Sex differentiation came about because it was a good strategy in terms of genetics and conception/gestational efficacy. Other good strategies may emerge and we don't know what they look like. We don't know what humanity will look like in the future because all we have to go on is what happened in the past, but the idea that "Adam and Eve" will somehow persist as some kind of divine norm strikes me as short-sighted. Within 5 - 10 years, same-sex couples will be able to reproduce biologically and their children will have exactly the same connection to the couple's lineage as do the biological children of heterosexuals. That's not an evolutionary consideration, but it's just one example of how things can change on a dime.

Comment: Physics isn't a hypothesis. Math isn't a hypothesis. We know how much fossil fuel we burn. We know how much additional CO2 that adds to the atmosphere. We know the physical properties of CO2. We know how much extra heat those physical properties will retain. We know how much the temperature will rise due to that additional CO2. We know none of the other potential causes of warming are present.

As the CO2 level has increased, the temperature has risen along with it. Even statistics gives us a 0.1% chance the rise in CO2 is not the cause of the warming.

It's not an experiment, it's mathematics.

Their goals and tactics are the same as Islamic State to the east. And the UN has already accused al-Nusra of using chemical weapons, including sarin.

A simple and plausible scenario is the following. Knowingly or otherwise, Syrian jets attacked an al-Nusra weapons cache concealed in a civilian area. The cache contained some of the chemical weapons that al-Nusra is known to have. The chemicals dispersed, killing civilians nearby. Rather than accept responsibility, al-Nusra blamed the deaths on the Syrian government.

Comment: .

"“A clear preference for a new electoral system, let alone a consensus, has not emerged,” Trudeau writes. “Furthermore, without a clear preference or a clear question, a referendum would not be in Canada’s interest.”

---

Unfortunately true.

And unfortunately, this is the right thing to do under the current circumstances.

Canadians, and all the federal political parties, have made it very clear that there is nothing resembling a consensus on what form "electoral reform" should take.

Nothing near a majority preference has emerged from the extensive consultations.

Best for Canada is to wait until Canadians have come to a more unified mind on what is needed in the way of "electoral reform".

Sad, because the current FPTP system is less than ideal, though it does have some merits.

To my mind, the "ranked ballot" would be the best combination of open democracy combined with producing effective government, but the nation is divided over what is best.

The people have spoken.

Comment: Paul, despite the media nonsense the greenhouse effect is elementary physics.  Yes, more greenhouse gas will cause warming.  How warm will it get, don't look to the media because the answer is too complicated.  It depends on the feedback mechanisms active.  For example, higher temperature causes more water to evaporate which might make more clouds and clouds defeat the greenhouse effect by reflecting solar energy directly back into space.  Called negative feedback.  Multiple mechanisms are active and the media cannot present a meaningful discussion.  Bottom line is that CO2 remains in the atmosphere for centuries thus depletion rate is very slow.  Unless we get emissions below the depletion rate CO2 will continue to accumulate.  To get below the depletion rate would require draconian elimination of fossil fuel burning everywhere and elimination of deforestation.  China would like to burn Nat gas but warmers won't let it be exported so China burns dirty coal.  Warmers cause warming.

Comment: Solar and wind as intermittent sources of electricity in the grid need to have back-up alternative sources that are continuously available and able to be turned up and down as needed. Natural gas power sources are able to meet this requirement. Ontario Professional Engineer (OSPE) has published a good explanatory document on this on their website (www. ospe.on.ca)

Solar and wind energy density is very small compared with traditional power sources. The cost of connecting large numbers of low capacity power sources to the grid is very high and explains how Ontario has spent billions on "improving and upgrading the grid" to connect these sources. Solar and wind may be fine for standalone on-site power sources, but make no sense at all to be power sources in the public shared electricity grid.

Comment: The writer may not realize that even though train horns don't bother him, they bother thousands of people in Eugene.  I just don't understand the lack of empathy of people who say the City shouldn't create a QZ because they personally aren't bothered by it.

He says he lives in the South Hills, where I live, and that the sound is "faint".  Not so!  It's loud enough to wake me up at night even through closed windows, though I am 3 miles away.  He may also not realize that the decibel level and frequency has increased in the past 10 years, per Federal law changes.

In terms of taxpayer cost for the QZ, it's an important issue because it involves the fundamental livability of Eugene, and people literally lose sleep over the issue.  With a QZ in place, the whole city will benefit economically, and eventually the QZ will pay for itself through increased economic activity.  Lot of development has been put on hold because of excessive train noise.

Comment: That's true but...

the higher you get on the income scale, the less income is derived from the sources that are taxed at the top marginal rate. For the richest taxpayers, most of their income is derived from capital gains which is taxed much lower than wages and salaries. What's important is the Effective Tax Rate which takes into account all taxes.

Here's a link to a CBO report from 2007 you may find interesting. It breaks down how the various "quintiles" of income are taxed. It also breaks down the highest quintile to numerous subsets of data since the top quintile consists of anyone in the upper middle class up to Bill Gates.

https://www.cbo.gov/publication/20374

So, when you hear that raising the top marginal rate will raise taxes a lot on rich folks - it won't. When you hear that poor people don't pay taxes - they do. I wholeheartedly agree with your post and I think this information will clarify a few things.

Comment: Speaking of EV pedal power, my latest vehicle is a hybrid, pedal power plus electric adult tricycle.

Lots of room in the plastic trunk at the back, 40 km range, more if I take the charger along. 

Rear fenders rear and lights are integrated into the trunk, a better choice than a wire cage here on the Left / Wet Coast.

The electric motor is rated at 250 watts and I can probably do another 200 watts myself.

It has dual disk brakes, front and back. The brake and throttle controls are on the handle.

Front and Rear LED lights work off the battery, so there is no generator drag when they are on. I turn them on when I ride, just as I do when I drove a car without Daytime Running Lamps. For some reason I am seeing automobiles with dark front lights again during the day in recent years. Wasn't that illegal on new cars for a while?

https://electricbikereport.com/wp-content/gallery/pedego-electric-bikes/pedego-electric-trike.jpg

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytime_running_lamp#Canada

Comment: The main concern of the tribes is that the pipeline would lie on the bottom of Lake Oahe upstream of drinking water intakes used by the tribe. This angered them because the original pipeline route was abandoned because it was upstream of water intakes for a large population of mostly white people living in the Bismarck area. Furthermore, the Treaty of Fort Laramie in 1868 granted the Indians all the land that the new pipeline crosses approaching the Missouri River. However, an act of Congress in 1877 took those and other lands from the Sioux Nation. Those tribes and their ancestors had used those lands for thousands of years. Comment: Kleptocracy (krátos, “power, rule”; klépto- thieves + -kratos rule, literally "rule by thieves") - is a government with corrupt leaders (kleptocrats) that use their power to exploit the people and natural resources of their own territory in order to extend their personal wealth and political power.

Kleptocracies are generally associated with dictatorships, oligarchies, military juntas, or other forms of autocratic and nepotist governments in which external oversight is impossible or does not exist. This lack of oversight can be caused or exacerbated by the ability of the kleptocratic officials to control both the supply of public funds and the means of disbursal for those funds. Kleptocratic rulers often treat their country's treasury as a source of personal wealth, spending funds on luxury goods and extravagances as they see fit. 

Kleptocracy is most common in developing countries whose economies are based on the export of natural resources.

Comment: The reason why aviation is such a safe way to travel is because of an over-abundance of caution- not too little of it. So while I think it's reasonable to continue studying the effects of fatigue on pilots, doing nothing about it in the meantime would be the height of irresponsibility.

Here is the hard truth. As complex as they are, it isn't the airplanes themselves that cause the most incidents and accidents in aviation. It's HUMAN FACTORS which cause or contribute heavily to the vast majority of air-related deaths. 

Aircraft engineers long ago surpassed the reliability of human crew members, to the point where a systems failure causing an unavoidable accident is now exceedingly rare. Instead it's human beings- typically the pilots- which are at fault most of the time.

We've reached the limit, pretty much, of mechanical safety in aviation. The only way to make flying safer now is to focus on the human side.

Comment: Mr Kaplan, good for you!  

You're quite right, democracy breaks down when people don't vote.  Look at the fluoride survey the City of PA conducted recently  --  it was described as worthless because only 45% of survey ballots were returned.  

But the same percentage of ballots were returned in the general election just before it.  In both cases, low participation means that a small minority gets to make the decisions for all of us  --  not a good idea, and not how democracy works.

Here in WA State, we don't even have to go to the polls  --  we have the easiest franchise in the US.  We can vote in our jammies at 3 am, we can google every single question, and someone else can drop our ballot off for us.

Fifteen years ago, our voter participation rates were something to be proud of  -- in the 70-percent range.  Lately, less than half of us have been voting, even though voting is easier than ever before.  

To make good decisions, we need all of us to chime in.

For health reasons, you would be wise to consume only wild fish and those from the US or other countries whose processing methods are considered safe.  Stay away from all farm raised fish, shrimp etc and those from
countries like India, Vietnam, China, Indonesia, Philippines and such places.

Comment: My older brother and I received an excellent public school education because of my mom's choice of schools and her constant monitoring of our progress through them.  She managed to teach us how to learn things on our own with weekly trips to the local libraries including university libraries.  It helped a great deal that she was college educated with a Master's degree and knew how to inspire us to read a great deal and learn how to learn.  She was a divorced working mother and I owe my success in life to her encouragement and dedication to education.
My wife and I raised a son and daughter in the public schools and we both helped them to learn how to learn.  Were we totally happy with the public schools they attended in the Mat-Su.  Not so much.  However there were more good things about their education than bad and they both have amazing and rewarding careers going for them.  With help from us and some very good teachers they both learned how to learn and will continue to learn.

Comment: Although I hope the addition of that language makes some kind of impact, I have to wonder if it will. People who allow their pet to roam un-tethered have rationalized their behavior and found a community of like-minded people, many of whom speak in a manner that indicates they truly believe they are morally superior to those who would "limit" their pets. And really, their behavior is rational. Don't we all seek to maximize benefit and minimize cost in nearly everything we do? Pet owners who refuse responsibility for restraining their pet seek to maximize the benefits of pet ownership (companionship, defense, conversational ice-breaker, etc.) while minimizing the cost (financial and convenience-wise). Meanwhile, the rest of us, including responsible pet owners, the pets themselves, and wildlife bear much of those costs. This practice is called externalizing costs, and it is how many industries, industries for which many of us have low regard, have made a great deal of money.

Comment: The Second Amendment doesn't mention guns, firearms, or any other weapon specifically. It mentions arms, and qualifies the right to keep and use them to only a "well regulated militia". Currently the Supreme Court has ruled that means that municipalities don't have the right to ban use of firearms by citizens, a right that was taken for granted for a hundred years. A future Supreme Court could overturn al prior interpretations, just as the Roberts court did. Any right can be qualified, as the First Amendment has been. The majority of US citizens would go along with strict limits on possession and use of firearms. At some point this will have to happen. The NRA is really screwing up by opposing all restrictions. The NRA should be working toward sensible regulation that would reduce gun deaths and save honest competent gun owners from outright confiscation. The "cold, dead hand" death fantasy is truly stupid.

Comment: What is misunderstood and not mentioned in this article is that a fiduciary standard would require an advisor never to recommend a financial product to a client that carried a commission or finder's fee if an identical product with no such fee or commission were available.  In effect, it would change the investor/advisor landscape to a pure hourly fee for service compensation arrangement.  That may be good or bad, but it is a key point to consider.  Many investors who are currently served by advisors would not avail themselves of the same service if it were only available under an hourly fee arrangement, particularly those investors with smaller portfolios.

Comment: DC plans are fine. They are not part of company assets, they're owned by the worker and can't be clawed back by an employer's bankruptcy.

As for the CPP, it is akin to DBs in the sense that it's more of a "promise" than a right. CPP was massively underfunded and in danger of insolvency until Paul Martin's drastic reforms in the 1990s slashed benefits. Thousands of soon-to-be retirees then learned that they weren't entitled to their entitlements after all.

As the pool of CPP contributions grows, there is greater and greater temptation for governments to tinker with the independence of the plan for one purpose or another.

The best remedy for this is to keep your retirement savings as far away from state control as possible. If there must be forced saving (and I'm not convinced it is necessary), then it should be made to an account that the worker has full property rights in, which can't be appropriated or interfered with by our wise and respected political leaders.

Comment: No problem, but lets also add statistical information rather than just citations:
According to the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), the US had an Intentional Homicide rate of 4.88 per 100k people in 2015, or 15,696 murders. During the same period, 371 mass shootings were reported (defined as at least 4 victims in a single event), that accounted for 469 fatalities or 3% of total deaths. According to FBI UCR in 2015 firearms were involved in 71.5% of homicides, compared to 11.5% edged weapons.

Now looking at Australia had 236 homicides, or .98 per 100k (UN). 27 were gun homicides, 0 were mass shootings. (gunpolicy.org)
Now looking at Ireland (UK did not report homicides 2015), Ireland had 30 homicides or .64 per 100k (UN). 10 were gun homicides, 0 were mass shootings. (gunpolicy.org)
Now Germany, 682 homicides or .85 per 100k (UN). 15 were gun homicides, 1 mass shooting. (gunpolicy.org)

Comment: One of the primary problems with the current ‘reform’ is the validity of the evaluation systems. If you or the paper or whoever is claiming that such selection is backed by valid longitudinal data showing significant improvement for a majority of students then such statements as yours are meaningful.  If that data does not exist then such statements are at best questionable if not wishful nonsense.
I am aware of data that shows a teacher can have a positive outcome longitude educational outcomes but I am not aware of data that shows the selection process is effective in selecting teachers who have positive outcomes across a range of educational objectives.
An attempt to improve selection data by increasing testing has proved to be counterproductive. There were good reasons to doubt the original premises six years ago of accountability and choice but the only data I have seen is that they are expensive but ineffective.

Comment: Balderdash indeed. Timber has always been boom and bust, a highly cyclical industry in which the common workers took the hits. Bidding for timber lots was never completely an open market, and most sales went below cost. In the Reagan land plunder, old forests were nearly liquidated, in most cases, never to return. Along with those forests went clean streams with healthy biota and lots of fish. 

Now one man (or woman) with a feller-buncher can clearcut a forest that formerly took a dozen sawyers and laborers. Limbing and trimming are automated as is yarding and loading the logs. The mills are highly computerized, using far few workers. That's why logging and milling are now a small sector of Oregon's economy.

As the author implies, though many former loggers blame the spotted owl and environmentalists, who should be call conservatives because they work for conservation, productivity gains from computers and mechanization have made the jobs disappear, never to return.

Comment: One other thing that Intensive management advocates won't tell you is even if prey species numbers go up, it's not necessarily because of predator control. It could be a natural swing because of a series of mild winters or the result of a natural event like a forest fire creating better habitat. 

And even if predator control worked and created way more animals, two things will probably happen. Number one is predator numbers will increase, because predator numbers trend the same as prey numbers. And any gain will only be temporary until habitat is damaged and a bad winter or two comes along and knocks the herd down. Then those extra animals will be a liability and cause damage to the habitat which will delay a recovery of the herd. Which of course intensive management buffs will blame on predators, not on their misguided vision of game management.

Comment: I know this is what is how it works within the Church - Canon Law jurisdiction.  But, no priest can "practice" in a diocese without the bishop's permission.  I have some concern that bishops may have learned of abuse by religious order clergy and did the nothing they did when it was a diocesan priest.  But, if someone had experienced abuse in a setting under the supervision of the bishop, I think the bishop should have responsibility under the civil law because he is the one who allows that person to work in the parish.  More, if there were complaints about the behavior of the clergyman or religious person, that would probably have gone up to the same people within the diocese whether the person was a diocesan priest or a person in a religious order.  

Why should what is recognized and permissible under U.S. law have to conform to Catholic Canon Law?  So far, I think U.S. law has recognized the distinction.  But I think it is disingenuous of bishops to make that claim.

Comment: The Scientific Method:
Purpose- What do you want to learn?
Research- Find out as much as you can.
Hypothesis- Try to predict the answer to the problem. Another term for hypothesis is ‘educated guess’. This is usually stated like ” If I…(do something) then…(this will occur)
Experiment- The fun part! Design a test or procedure to confirm or disprove your hypothesis.
Analysis- Record what happened during the experiment. Also known as ‘data’.
Conclusion- Review the data and check to see if your hypothesis was correct.

The AGW Method:
Purpose: What do you want to convince people of?
Research:  Only pursue research that supports your objective by providing correlation, even if it doesn't prove causation.
Hypothesis:  Try to predict the answer to the problem.  (Models)
Experiment:  If the results don't confirm your predictions, change the data history and current sources to make the results fit the predictions.

You can't do an experiment because there are far too many variables.

Comment: There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years.  Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: Mr. Apo correctly points out that nearly every "Native Hawaiian" also has genealogy from other ethnicities.  Maybe 3/4 of "Native Hawaiians" each has 3/4 of his/her genealogy that is other than "Native Hawaiian."  

That's why it's false to say that "Native Hawaiians" have the worst statistics for diabetes, heart disease, breast cancer, incarceration, drug abuse, etc.  Here's what's going on.  When someone gathers data on diabetes, they ask the victims "Are you Native Hawaiian?"  The victim (having 1/8 Hawaiian blood) says yes.  End of story.  The statistician does not count that person as a member of any of his other ethnicities.  How absurd is that?  The right way to do the analysis is to count 1/8 of a tally mark for "Native Hawaiian", 1/8 for Caucasian, 1/4 for Japanese, and 1/2 for Chinese.  If ethnic data were counted correctly for any category of victimhood, "Native Hawaiians" would not be falsely portrayed as the world's biggest victims.

Comment: Bad analysis here.  As Torbay mentioned, the gross cost for the Tesla roof is only $34,300.  If the alternative is a regular roof for $10k, then a cheap $10k shingle roof will only last around 20 - 25 years in Cali.  So you've got around $14k in roofing costs over that 30-year period time.  The net cost of the solar feature is then $20k.

You're looking at the utility bill savings that this $20k gives you versus putting it in an investment.  $76,700 is the amount of savings given in the article.  What kind of return do you need on the $20k to get $76.7k after 30 years? Answer = 4.6%, AFTER TAX.  Still, if you can achieve your 6% after tax on the investment account then, yes, you would be better off investing the $20k.  But there are two big problems here: (a) 6% after tax is closer to 10% gross return, a difficult feat to achieve these days, and (b) the risk profiles of the two are completely different.  A better comparison is a 30-year US gov bond: 3.0%. I'd take the solar.

Comment: You're right in this regard:  The abortion issue turns not on religion, as Don Alexander would have it, but on the question:  What is this newly conceived being?  If the answer is, "A human being," then its life is as worthy as a new born's.  If something else, then abortion is no big deal.

You say the matter is one of opinion.  But opinions are given weight to the extent the square with facts, with reality.  No one doubts that a newly conceived zygote is a unique and discrete living being.  Nor can there be any doubts that its being is human.  It simply can't be anything OTHER than human.  It is, then, an actual --- not potential but actual --- living human being.  Thus, we can justify abortion only if we say that we can kill a living human being without violating the right to life.  That is an extreme, self-contradictory position.

Comment: I can illustrate one obvious reason why sexual assaults are under-reported.

It's an office Christmas party where alcohol is being consumed. A man into his cups suddenly grabs a co-worker's breast. That's a sexual assault under the Criminal Code. Will the victim of the assault press charges with the police? Most likely not. The man will be admonished by his co-workers and employer, and possibly lose his job. But few people in that situation, including the victim, want to see the offender receive a criminal conviction for his behavior.

By definition, the crime of sexual assault covers everything from the most horrific, violent attack on a helpless adolescent right down to the example I gave above. Yet many feminist advocates insist that sexual assault of even the most minor kind is misogynist and evil. And they've pushed society and its justice system in that direction. Until a more nuanced view of the issue comes about, sexual assaults will continue to be under-reported.

Comment: It's not a qualifying statement; rather a prefatory clause. This is supposed to be an honest discussion, remember? It's purpose is to inform as to the reason why the existing right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed by the general government. The right protected (not established) by the 2nd Amendment is the right to keep and bear arms by the citizens of the States. The Constitution is a document of negative liberties, restrictions on the power and reach of the general government, remember? The amendment prohibits the federal government from infringing upon the existing right of the people to keep and bear arms. That restriction applies just as much today as it did when the amendment was ratified.

Coupled with recent tests, nuclear capability, an increasingly hostile tone and vexing unpredictability, Kim's North Korea has become the world's diplomatic dilemma.
.
“We can expect an [intercontinental ballistic missile] test this year with full capability within the next few years,” former CIA official Bruce Klingner told Fox News earlier this month.
.
“North Korea almost certainly already has the ability to target South Korea and Japan, and U.S. forces based in both countries, with nuclear weapons carried on the No Dong medium-range ballistic missiles," former CIA Deputy Division Chief for Korea Bruce Klingner told Fox News. "After missile test launches last year, Pyongyang declared that they were practicing nuclear air-burst attacks on South Korea.”
.
Technology exists now for stopping a North Korean missile launch Herman wrote. "It’s called boost-phase intercept, or BPI, and the U.S. and Japan have the means to deploy it."

Comment: "Nothing vague here...."

The very fact they are using lifetime stats is a purposeful attempt to shift the statistic away from the x/100K or x/1000 rate metrics all social sciences and police forces have been using for half a century, now.

Look at the CDC study in the US, of the infamous "1 in 5 women will be sexually assaulted while at university" stat. They included unwanted kissing, touching over the clothes, sex while drunk, and included a positive consent requirement not found in the legal definition.  Use those CDC numbers and my Alma Mater, with 17 385 female students, would be seeing 3477 every four years, or 870 a year . That is a farcical stat. The school would shut down and no one would send their daughters.

Canada surveys the public directly, using the GSS, and we use the legal definition when we do. The rate? 22/1000/5rs, or 4.4/1000 annually.  With the GSS stat, my Alma Mater should see about 78 a year. What actually gets reported? Single digits or low double digits.

But, this went against Prince Kuhio's secondary argument that the "Rehabilitation Act", as it was commonly called at the time, was not just a back to the land opportunity, but to "save a dying race". In addition, there was only so much land, and there wouldn't be enough for all, let alone folks with greater blood quantum. So, the 50% amount was agreed upon.
In any case, almost 100 years later we know that Polynesian-Hawaiians are NOT a "dying race" and the program has been a dismal failure, as well as all the other 800 plus Polynesian-Hawaiian only raced based programs in this state.

Comment: This is not a well written or researched article and it makes me wonder what agenda the author is following. He may not be but this ill-researched badly thought out piece tends to suggest that he is not that competent at what he does or he is being influenced in some way.

What we have here is the classic straw man - presenting a ludicrous hypothesis to discredit a broader body of evidence.

It is important to note that the physical properties of EMR, its ability to heat water, it's NON ionising properties and the extent to which single strength is inversely related to the square of the distance from the emitter - are all NON disputed facts of science and all have absolutely no bearing on the actual issues with EMR which are namely the physiological effects observed at levels well below ICNIRP safety limits which themselves are only based on thermal properties. To say there is overwhelming evidence of safety is just plain wrong. The evidence to the contrary is extensive and growing

Comment: If you are not an electrician, buy a copy of the Canadian Electrical Code and get a homeowner's permit.  It WILL be inspected but you can do it legally and safely yourself if you follow code.

If you buy your panels on line, remember they must be CSA certified to be legal in Canada.  There are suppliers in Canada, but I don't know where in the country you live so I can't recommend anyone. 

My local supplier would be

http://www.batteryworld.ca/

You should be paying no more than $1 per watt for the panels themselves.  I.e. A 240 watt panel should cost around $240. 

Remember that you could invalidate your fire insurance if you don't get a permit/inspection.

Comment: Much of what is reported in this interesting piece is aided and abetted by...instant communications; it becomes a catch-22: the means of communicating to millions anytime feeds on itself.  Thinking time is short because the ability to deliver a message is there, waiting and--worse--the Pres. is a tweet junkie. So many mistakes or "mispeaking" or "missteps" occur simply because there is little time to reflect, and a decision to "say nothing right now" is rare.  That's the sending end.  On the receiving end, much of the public are now 24/7 news junkies, slavering for updates even when there really aren't any.  Legitimacy is threatened.  Hence, "fake news."

Just a century ago, it was different: no instant mass communication. As most people did NOT live in cities, many never read one of the handful of daily newspapers.  Many were illiterate, most had no telephone.  News travelled more slowly; next week was good enough.  Result: Less "news."  Not today.  Result: chaos reign

Comment: I believe you are exactly right:  AI will automate millions of jobs out of existence, beginning with driving-related ones over the next 5 - 10 years.  Office and knowledge workers will not be immune.  At first, it will be a gradual shift, where AI will take on an "assist" role: head-office will not lay off Tim in Finance to be replaced by a robot right away, but they won't hire that extra headcount or contract worker.  But with increasing workplace penetration, machine learning and algorithms will start improving exponentially, and eventually supplant more and more people.  I could see very significant impacts on employment and society within the next 15-20 years.  Is it reasonable to think that new jobs and professions will sprout to replace the old ones?  Maybe, but many (most) will remain under or unemployed. What will people do without meaningful work?  How will they pay for food and rent?  Brace for huge social unrest and accelerated wealth concentration at the top of the pyramid.

Comment: This is not speculation or propaganda, though. The information security community knows, not  everything, but a lot about the computer network exploitation capabilities of most large nation states. China, like the US, runs this as a military capability, but their teams are a lot more decentralized than American hackers. Russia is quite different altogether. We know the general methodologies that each prefers (which often reflect the organizational structure), the kinds of tools each prefers, and we know the types of targets they go after.

People who study this have access not only to forensic analysis of breaches, but also get a lot of data from accidental leaks, and often the attackers' servers are compromised, with contents then publicized. US and Cdn intel services know even more than is public, because they directly attack Russian and Chinese hacker groups.

You can choose not to believe it, but that is not something you can reconcile with objective facts.

Fake news.

Comment: "... we are losing our culture."
No, our culture is evolving. We are constantly evolving. Look back at the 30s and 40s - we were very different even in the 70s, and in the 90s, so can it be a surprise that we're different now compared to then?
I've been to France several times. I enjoy the food but a 2-hour dinner is a little too long. Perhaps in the Victorian era, where there were far fewer things to enjoy, lingering over a limp salad or stringy steak was the way to kill some time, but I have far too many things to enjoy and sometimes my lunch or dinner are brief because of that.
Is it wrong? I don't think so. I enjoy cooking, and obviously eating, but food is not the center of my world, merely a part of what I define as my day.
Ms. Waters is certainly free to have opinions that differ than mine, but I would disagree over which of us enjoys the better life. Enjoying time with friends and family is certainly enjoyable, but dawdling over food at a snail's pace isn't essential."

Comment: Not only should Pebble NOT be developed, the entire Bristol Bay area should be set aside as a national monument. Yes, it would be huge, but that's necessary to conserve the rivers, watershed and  bay waters the fish rely on to spawn. Developing the mine would permanently damage the region, and the imprint would last for centuries.  You can close off a shaft mine once you are done using it , and green up the surroundings,but you  can't  do that with an open pit mine. You cant fill in an open pit mine, certainly not one the size that Pebble is proposing to build. We're  talking the worlds largest open pit mine here, a mile deep with a  huge dam needed to hold the tailings back, for posterity. We already saw such a dam fail at Mount Polley in Canada, so the track record ain't great.  Best to leave the area as is, as Teddy Roosevelt said about the Grand Canyon " Leave it be, for your children and your children's children. The ages have done their work on it, and man can only mar it."

Comment: One thing BC did not get on top of, that led to price escalation, was shadow flipping and assignment of contracts.

You could sell your house to person A, and before the sale closed it could be resold to someone else for more money, with the original owner being none the wiser. To make it worse, profit taken from repeated sales before closing was never taxed, making this type of transaction very popular.

Unscrupulous real estate agents were also telling clients to take the first offer (to facilitate this).  They were also refusing to take offers from other agencies so they could claim both the buyer and seller commissions.

It took forever to get the BC Liberals to acknowledge the problems and scams, and they only acted after an expose from the Globe's Kathy Tomlinson forced their hand.

Comment: Federal law (Title 3, chapter 1, section 6 of the United States Code) requires the states to report the November popular vote numbers (the "canvas") in what is called a "Certificate of Ascertainment." 

Article III of The Agreement Among the States to Elect the President by National Popular Vote:

"The chief election official of each member state shall determine the number of votes for each presidential slate in each State of the United States and in the District of Columbia in which votes have been cast in a statewide popular election and shall add such votes together to produce a "national popular vote total" for each presidential slate. "

The popular-vote count from each state would be added up to obtain the nationwide total for each candidate

Under the current system, the electoral votes from all 50 states are co-mingled and simply added together for the Electoral College vote.

Comment: As it did with South African apartheid, the international community has spoken concerning Israel's unjust policies towards Palestinians. But let's not kid ourselves: just like the Afrikaaners, Israelis are proud and independent. Israel will hate being told what to do. It will surely resist international opinion, just as South Africa did. 

There were a number of nations that were only lukewarm in opposing South African apartheid, and some that refused to apply sanctions when called on to do so. Israel was one of them. However, in the end, without a shot being fired over the issue, South Africa eventually relented to international pressure and did the right thing.

To be sure, doing the right thing in Palestine won't magically transform the area into a New Eden. Political, social and security problems will continue, just as they did in SA. But by removing an impediment to justice and equality, a much greater conflict was averted in South Africa. The same is true in this case.

Comment: According to national standardized test scores, Hawaii's public schools are not much better than they were 30 years ago.  An identified problem is that the central DOE bureaucracy is making too many decisions for the individual schools, even though the bureaucrats don't have a good idea of the conditions each school faces.  Clearly, the faculty of each school should be making most of the decisions that affect student learning.  Budgetary decisions are key.  

By law, at least 70% of the total State budget for education should be expended by school principals (HRS 302A-1301).  However, the DOE is not complying with the spirit of the law, and school principals have discretion over only about 50% of the education budget.  It is true that some principals are successful, but they are too few and too far between.  They succeed in spite of the DOE bureaucracy and not because of it.

Comment: Real,

It's good to remember that around 2004-5 several of our Chartered Banks lobbied to be allowed to merge and participate directly in the US high octane securitization market (CDO3 et al) but that the Department of Finance and Bank of Canada said no; they would not be allowed to consolidate of to participate in the securitization market except in the relatively 'boring' Canadian version.

There was much moaning in the Canadian financial industry that this doomed them to indefinitely remain a backwater.  However, by 2009 6 of the 10 largest North American Banks by capitalization were Canadian Chartered Banks because of the losses incurred by the leading US Banks.

In short, regulation by Federal Government and agencies in Canada were instrumental in saving our Chartered Banks, our domestic financial system and the Canadian Government and people loads of money and the preventing a deep domestic depression from occuring here.

Royalty rates and taxes also impact revenue.

Comment: Depends on how wisely one invested.

Do you think the money you contributed to social security is sitting in some government fund gaining interest waiting for you to draw it out??? I got news for ya...the money you contributed has already been spent on some other guy or gal or child. The only way you'll see any social security payment is if several people continue to work and put their funds into social security. 
To compare social security to a private investment is folly. If you step back and look at social security it resembles more of a ponzi scheme than any type of investment. You buy into social security, what you contribute is given out to someone who bought in earlier, long before you ever get a chance to withdraw funds, and the only way you'll see any return is if some other person buys in...actually several others need to buy in.
Isn't that the definition of a ponzi scheme??

Comment: You are missing the big picture: 

With car connectivity the future can hold the following,

COLLISION AVOIDANCE - could reduce fatalities and injuries by 30% worldwide (this alone is worth it)
ROAD HAZARD WARNINGS - If the infrastructure can communicate with oncoming vehicles, it can warn of road works or a reduced speed area. 
SENSOR FUSION, AUTOMATION  -Further steps in the benefits of connectivity can be achieved via sensor fusion, with on-board active safety devices, sensors and map data.
KNOWLEDGE BASE - All the driving data generated could be used to analyse situations, where safety systems take over in an emergency situation to prevent an accident. 
REAL-TIME TRAFFIC INFORMATION  -A connected car collects and makes position and speed data available to other cars as well as the infrastructure. It will reduce congestion, fuel consumption, and time spent in transit. It can find parking spots, fuel stops (Electric, gas, Hydrogen, etc)

Comment: "... violated ... rights to life, liberty, and property ... failed to protect essential public trust ..."  OK, fair enough - the famous "penumbras" of Constitutional law here, and our "evolving standards".

Comment: All of this navel gazing and political posturing really won't make a lot of difference.   In the end, Crown Counsel still have to use the test of "is there a likelihood of obtaining a conviction."  If there isn't, charges won't be laid.   If they succumb to pressure such as these articles and lay charges lacking adequate evidence, the courts will let them know in very clear terms.  
So, by all means, ensure that the police do their job in an adequate manner, and that Crown is made aware of the nuances, (here you may want to read "Men bad, women believable victims always").  But if there isn't sufficient evidence to convict, the courts won't do it.  And, bad case law emerging from trials entered into for political expediency will just make it more difficult for other, more valid prosecutions.

Comment: ."..most of the distribution is the insurance company giving you your money back (or the principal of some other person who didn't outlive you)"

Although you imply this is a fault, in fact the redistribution of funds to survivors is a valuable aspect of pooled annuity or "tontine" schemes.

This is because no one knows exactly how long they will live. Therefore each individual faces two problems: (1) running out of money, or (2) dying rich.  However, when funds are pooled among a large group of people it is possible to predict average mortality and assure income to survivors.

Christianity isn't Islam or Judaism founded on a book that lists naughty and nice things to do. Comment: Now you are just being baffling - please point out where I ".... repeatedly call(ed) for more evidence ..." or "... use(d) irrelevant arguments ..." in my remarks above.

The only way to determine whether the predictions of numerical climate models (imaginary worlds) make any useful sense is to compare their results with actual observations of the Real World.  (It's pretty straight forward, if you think about it ...)  :-/

The earth has been here before.

Comment: In other words, an older person with greater life experiences is better able to see patterns and subtleties. While the younger person lacking life experience must rely on a more literal interpretation.

Mental sharpness also doesn't decline with age, what comes with age is greater clarity and understanding. The ability to see the multitude of answers that exists, rather than seeing just that one answer the younger person quickly produces.

As for dementia, how active you keep your mind has no bearing on the disease. As one professor of neurology put it “We should probably assume that a significant proportion of those over the age of 65 have impairment of executive function. These are the complex cognitive processes that guide normal decision-making. The onset of these changes can be sudden, as in a stroke, or slower, as a result of microbleeds or routine, age-related changes to brain structure.”

Comment: We've live out in the country for 45  years and have had "our share" of road kills.  Believe me, no one looks to hit a deer intentionally. Even if you salvage the meat, say 40 pounds, you end up paying about $20/pound or more after repairing your car.  You're far more likely to find a recent road kill and salvage the meat while some other person incurred the damage to his/her car.  Sure beats wasting the meat and having a carcass sit on the roadway or shoulder rotting for days.  I will "take the Fifth" regarding the many roadkill deer I've "met" over the years, but will offer that roadkill venison tastes a lot like "hunted" venison.  An additional bonus....the county or state road department staff won't have to remove as many of those old rotting carcasses. 

Not to be too snide, but I think this bill is the highlight of the legislative session.  Gary Crum

Comment: Two reasons for increased non-mortgage debt. Householders with good jobs but overwhelmed with mortgage debt and payments due to soaring house prices over the past four or five years lack disposable income and take on more non-mortgage debt to get by,  as other needs and costs mount over time.  Householders who have lost good jobs, e.g Alberta, Newfoundland, but still have high credit limits, take on non-mortgage debt to manage . More stringent rules for mortgage eligibility are good, but hardly address the problems caused by lax rules and soaring house prices in the past, much less job loss.  In the past debt burden from housing arose from two sources: house prices and mortgage rates. Reducing mortgage rates and increasing wages could relieve debt and increase disposable income.  The first is no longer an option. The second won't happen in an economy based on real estate and its offshoots, as in BC and Ontario, rather than real business investment.

Comment: The federal U.S. Appeals Court refused to reinstate Donald Trump's travel ban.

Section 212(f) of the U.S. Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 states: “Whenever the President finds that the entry of any aliens or of any class of aliens into the United States would be detrimental to the interests of the United States, he may by proclamation, and for such period as he shall deem necessary, suspend the entry of all aliens or any class of aliens as immigrants or nonimmigrants, or impose on the entry of aliens any restrictions he may deem to be appropriate.”

Congress gave that power to U.S. presidents. In fact, one source says "the past six presidents have all used the executive power to bar different classes of immigrants". That included some Muslims.

So does that decision by the 3 U.S. Appeals Court judges mean Section 212(f) of the U.S. Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 is useless and meaningless?

Comment: The storage of extra rims is a pain, but cheaper and quicker than switching tires on the same rims. 
I used to pull the studs every other year, when I had more time and energy, and have the studs replaced - as one or two seasons is about the best you can expect  from steel stud s- less recently with climate change impacts on winter roads- . and the fellow who used to re-stud my tires for me retired (not "re-tired"), :>)
I tried Blizzteks for two years and liked their performance, but they wore down as quickly as do steel studs, and are more expensive to replace.
Overall tho, I'd like to definitely add that driving more slowly in winter; staying aware of skidding tendencies of curves and on hills  - especially at lights or stop signs - , and keeping greater distances between you and other vehicles can help almost as much as studs... and please stay far more alert for pedestrians, critters and cyclists!!

Comment: People should make note of Cowper's comment that the:  "general understanding was that the fund's purpose was to provide some of the money needed to pay for state government when the inevitable decline occurred at Prudhoe Bay."   That was the fund's purpose.   Note it says to provide SOME of the money needed to pay for state services.   Remember we had an income tax back then, ensuring that most Alaskan families contributed to the cost of State services.   The PFD was designed to keep citizens engaged, not supplant a broad based income tax.   Services are tied to population levels.   Income taxes are also tied to population levels, the more people the more expenses, so the more revenue.     We're the only state without a broad based tax to tie these two together.  Even Hammond recognized the problem with that.   2% income tax, 2% sales tax, 5% of the PFD earnings for revenue.   If there's money left over, distribute it; if not, cover the shortfall with savings.   Keeps us engaged.

Comment: 85 submissions about the proposed million-cubic-meter nuclear waste mound on the Canadian Environmental Assessment Registry website raise  troubling factual concerns about this project. (http://www.ceaa.gc.ca/050/documents-eng.cfm?evaluation=80122&type=3)   Placing large quantities of plutonium isotopes and other long-lived radionuclides in an above-ground facility is completely at odds with International Atomic Energy Agency guidance on radioactive waste disposal.   Former AECL scientists are speaking out because of genuine concern that future Ottawa Valley inhabitants may intrude into the mound and receive radiation doses exceeding current limits.   The technology and location of the proposed facility are inappropriate to deal with the very serious "legacy waste" problems at Chalk River, dating back to Canada's participation in Cold War atomic weapons related activities.  The long-term societal consequences of the proposal make it essential that politicians and the public have a say.

Comment: This comment is in response to the updated story, as of May 18.

U of Ottawa criminologist says, "‘Okay, we were premature in dismissing this one. Let’s go back,’” she said. “If unfounded goes down, what goes up? Is it the charging rate that goes up?"

A good question.  But that would only be step one.  The better question is one to ask if charges result in sexual assault trials.  Question then would be, over time,  "Is it the conviction rate that goes up?"  Yet another question: "If not...why not?"

If the outcome is just "another category, such as ‘founded not solved,’ you wonder if there’s been change or if it’s just a public relations exercise.”  the same thing I wonder about "unfounded" right now: what the heck does THAT mean?  The "founded" example given is meaningless. You can only "solve" something if there's crime.  "Unfounded" means, no crime.  "Founded" doesn't mean there's a crime--nobody knows until the case goes to court.  Try this: "Not enough evidence to proceed."

But that's not what they're doing. They're asking for political party as well. Why for could you possibly want THAT information? A fraudulent voting record is fraudulent regardless of political affiliation. Could they want that for voter suppression, perhaps? Things that make you go....Hmmmmmmmmmmmm.

Comment: Congratulations Bob on your new book on Dick Fosbury!  I admire your rigor in pushing through to finish this book while still attending to your RG duties.  Sounds like a great topic and you've covered it well.  
Being one of those who still  vividly remembers  the '68 Olympics and its context of world-wide tumult I see this being sort of  a high jump version of Boys in the Boat.   But the Fosbury Flop! Hard to believe a kid from  Medford turned the old "scissors" method in to a radical new technique.  To think, athletes for centuries had been trying to jump higher and then along comes Fosbury from Oregon to revolutionize the sport.   Now the heights jumpers reach using Fosbury's technique are astronomical.  
It seems to reflect the old Southern Oregon "Never give an inch" attitude from  Kesey's Great Notion to the Grant's Pass bus tragedy of '48.
Good luck with this one Bob.  It's the kind of inspiration we need.

Comment: "Remember, [Hallowe'en] was the day where children would dress up as something they were not." Well not exactly, it's quite the reverse. Hallowe'en was the day when people would dress up as *the someone they most profoundly were, or yearned deep-down that they could bring into the light of day and make real* -- like the Lord of Misrule and Twelfth Night. On Hallowe'en and holidays like it, they were allowed to liberate their real selves from the bondage of their everyday roles and their orthodox politesse -- from their scripts in the theatre of propriety and ordinary life. However, our fastidious and hypersensitive age has lost touch with the rich, wise past and has turned things on their heads. It is now transforming one of our very few intervals of liberation into a day on which we must intensify the conventions and repressions that we act out during the rest of the year. Today's Hallowe'en is a masquerade all right -- it's a travesty of the "holidays" of yesteryear.

Comment: For example. I have a colleague who had only been in private practice for a year, and was working in a large center, he suffered a debilitating injury to his spine in a car accident. Let's assume (generously), that he made $150,000 in his first year out of school. Now, he is unable to practice dentistry, unable to collect EI, his private disability insurance only pays him $5,000/month (at least he bought some!), yet he still has over $240,000 in student loans. Long story short, he's screwed. His options for paying back his loan are incredibly bleak, unless he returns to school and obtains another degree, incurring further debt, and how do we know if he will even be able to work again?

Also, we have a massive amount of professional fees and insurances to pay, so that if we ever do have an unfortunate event and get sued, we won't be starving. Furthermore, our job is stressful and highly skilled. We also don't get a pension or RRSP contributions for dividends. It's not like we are loaded

Comment: When was the last time anyone had an engine failure?  Do you even know someone who has had an engine failure?  I change the oil on my truck some unknown time after the oil change notification comes on and I have over 400,000 km on my truck without an engine repair.  The typical distance is 15,000 km between changes.  Modern engines simply do not fail with reasonable maintenance and most people spend money changing the oil excessively for no reason.  Changing the oil is for the next owner so wasting money on excessive oil changes makes no sense.  If you lease a vehicle for two or three years and then give them back, don't waste your money doing any maintenance at all.  If you decide that your existing vehicle has only a couple of years left in it, then again, stop doing maintenance.  My old minivan hit 350,000 km and I did no maintenance at all for three years then sold it at auction for $500.

Comment: Unable to agree on any particular method for selecting presidential electors, the Founding Fathers left the choice of method exclusively to the states in Article II, Section 1
“Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors….”  
The U.S. Supreme Court has repeatedly characterized the authority of the state legislatures over the manner of awarding their electoral votes as "plenary" and "exclusive." 
		
The National Popular Vote bill would replace state winner-take-all laws that award all of a state’s electoral votes to the candidate who get the most popular votes in each separate state (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), in the enacting states, to a system guaranteeing the majority of Electoral College votes for, and the Presidency to, the candidate getting the most popular votes in the entire United States.

Comment: What is really sad is the jealousy shown by a couple posters here. 

$1,000,000 in 'investable' assets really isn't that much.  Most financial advisors recommend a 4% withdrawal rate in retirement (I would use the dividend return on my portfolio - currently just under 5%). 

That means an annual income of $40,000 - $50,000 per year plus CPP & OAS. This is a comfortable retirement but certainly not a 'jet setting, luxurious' retirement.  It doesn't even get one into the OAS clawback range. 

Plus, one has to work quite hard and save quite diligently to achieve this.  I am not a business person, just a greasy fingered tradesman that has spent my share of time in the trenches, mud and cold and I am hoping to reach this milestone before my body gives out on me.

Comment: Peter, you are right about the traditional kapu practices, and indeed this is not just a Hawaiian feature, but now a common feature of nearly all Pacific island cultures.  The other critical component to traditional area management is a chief or designee whose job it is to know the health of the system by moving about and observing it and speaking with folks, so that appropriate and adaptive behavior can be set forward by the chief.   Such practices are not that uncommon now in modern fisheries, and on a much larger scale as well, plus there are kapu zones for the aquarium fishery in Kona that are now called "Fish Replenishment Zones".  

When there were fewer people, more observant chiefs, and a benign world, this highly flexible system probably worked just fine.  However, as you yourself point out, we are in a different world now.  There are many many more people.  Fishing pressure is much higher due both to the number of fishermen and the technology now available.  It's different.

Comment: Any comment suggesting that the penal system is somehow lenient to people convicted of sex offenses is misinformed.  The sentences are long, and the supervision through probation officers and registration is long, with tightly enforced conditions.  For example, the comment below about 20 year sentences being needed is uninformed.  A sex abuse or assault in the first degree now carries a range of 25 to 35 year sentence for a first offender.  Most sex crimes are less serious in nature, e.g. drunken touching of the chest, and result in years in prison along with up to 15 years of supervision.  Many individuals who commit these crimes are relatively young and immature and obviously unlikely to re-offend.  The system, along with torch and pitchfork attitude of the community, makes life (eg., simply working and living) almost unbearable.  For the more serious offenses, and the repeaters, the punishment makes a lot of sense.  For many, however, it does not, and Wohlforth's piece is valuable.

Comment: "Canadians are allowed under the Charter to make derogatory remarks about specific groups."

All Canadians have a limited Charter right to make certain kinds of derogatory comments, either about specific groups or individuals. That right is constrained in law, just as it is in every other civilized country. If you'd prefer to live where people have the right to say whatever they want about whoever they want, then you'll have to find an uncivilized country to live in. 

In the USA people even have the limited right to fight back physically against some kinds of speech. The USA recognizes that some kinds of speech are so provocative that they're akin to initiating violence, against which the listener may retaliate with violence to defend himself.

Comment: The State is self-insured for the plan provided by the commissioner of administration.   The Public Safety Employees Association want an independent union-run trust to provide HI and other benefits and the State foolishly agreed to it.   The State would normally stop making HI contributions when an employee leaves pay status, no matter the reason.   I suspect both of these Troopers were in Tier II or later PERS, which doesn't offer retiree and dependent HI until age 55.   Troopers can retire as young as 38 or so, and I suspect both these guys were caught in that gap.   I'd have just called PSEA and done a letter of agreement continuing to make active emplooyee HI contributions until the spouse remarried or the kids reached majority.   DOA could have done this with the stroke of a pen; don't know why it became such an issue.

Comment: There is a mistaken belief within the Public Service in the notion of "the generic manager".  That is, once someone possesses the qualities of a competent manager, you can pretty much parachute them in anywhere, and they'll do just fine.  Admittedly, there are some management/leadership positions where that can be true.  But there are an awful lot of leadership positions where some expertise in the substance of the file is of inestimable help in being able to have a vision of what needs to be done, being able to plan and summon the needed resources, and both establish and communicate a plan for implementation.  One doesn't have to be incompetent to be unsuitable.  All you need is insufficient command of the file to be an effective leader.  A lot of that going around.

Comment: While I concur with most of your comments, I'm not sure that the union is correct in adding to the costs. Adding more costs to the running of colleges will just increase tuition costs for the students. I, too, teach at a college part-time, and marking and other time is covered by the hourly classroom teaching amount. The college uses an informal ratio of two or three hours for every hour in the classroom for part-timers. The issue though is with full-time faculty, they are well paid for what they do. I've done the math, and the full-timers receive, when compared on an hourly basis, way more than the part-timers, as well as, they have benefits, a pension, and lots of time off. Administration  and full-time faculty costs are very high, and those costs should be examined, with the goal of keeping tuition manageable for our students. Many have to rely on OSAP. So, costs to run the colleges are high, and many students then incur debt to the government to pay for their education. Hmmm...

Comment: I used to fly a lot for work earlier in my career,  both domestically and internationally. There are things I found to be universally true. I never found a single airline that was perfect but some are definitely better than others. Alaska definitely falls into that "better" class. The other thing I found was how the passenger reacted to a bad situation often determined their outcome. When things were going wrong and I  had to work with an agent to fix things I always found being calm, a little sympathetic to their situation and a little flexible went a long way. These agents ars just people like you and I with a limited capacity to fix things. When a flight gets cancellled they suddenly have several hundred unhappy people to deal with. Being demanding, boorish and sometimes utterly rude to them won't  necessarily change their options. I once followed a guy who screamed how important he was at an agent. While she couldnt get him on the next flight she got me on ..upgraded to 1st class!!

Comment: Another issue that has been ignored is the unfair or inequitable treatment of homeowners and other asset owners regarding income on capital gains. In a logical world all income would be taxed the same. This would include salaries, capital gains on home sales, professional income, and capital gains on stock or other asset sales. This would go a long way to take some of the heat out of the real estate and stock markets, as both are inflated assets (aka bubbles). But if one wishes to maintain the capital gains exemptions on homes, it could be made more equal if it was a once in a lifetime thing and it was only for the average value of a home in Canada at the time of the claim, so the playing field was more equitable or equal. Increasing the holding period from one year to a five year minimum, with the holder being required to have paid personal income tax in Canada for that period might also help. These are all understandable and addressable issues.

Comment: Pro-Russian Bots Take Up The Right-Wing Cause After Charlottesville

Angee Dixson joined Twitter on Aug. 8 and immediately began posting furiously — about 90 times a day. A self-described American Christian conservative, Dixson defended President Donald Trump’s response to the unrest in Charlottesville, criticized the removal of Confederate monuments and posted pictures purporting to show violence by left-wing counter protesters.

The same social media networks that spread Russian propaganda during the 2016 election have been busily amplifying right-wing extremism surrounding the recent violence in Charlottesville, according to researchers who monitor the activity. It’s impossible to tell how much of the traffic originates from Russia or from mercenary sources. But there were hordes of automated bots generating Twitter posts and much more last week to help make right-wing conspiracy theories and rallying cries about Charlottesville go viral.

2.  In   "      there were 3,474 seminarians in the US and in 2015 it was slightly up to 3650
3.  In 2000 there was 74% of all diocesan priests in active ministry, in 2015 it had dropped to 66%.

In this way, we all can start to resolve the unique issues that are not common to all citizens.

Comment: As a parent of one of the protesting students, I will share that my son (who hasn't missed a day of school all year apart from the snow/ice days, and who is a hard-working student) is respectful of all adults, but is learning to think critically and historically about what is asserted in the public sphere.  Initially, he was dubious about the value of the protest (which we parents were unaware of), so when he asked his father and me to sign the permission slip (which explicitly stated that the school didn't support it), we asked what had changed.  He said simply that he felt that the EarthGuardians were right that we need to think seriously about Climate Change and how we can work to improve our impact.  I told him that if his academic or attendance record were not sufficient, I would not support his choice, but they are solid, so I signed.   I agree with my son that we need to work harder to SEE the problems around us, and incrementally change our ways, and I am proud of him.

Comment: Do the maintenance or look in the yellow pages for a chimney sweep. That gadget referred to above isn't that expensive either. As another reader mentioned, your local fire department has loaner brushes, so it helps if you know the diameter of the flue when you go to borrow them.

 A sweep can inspect the chimney to make sure it's not compromised, esp if you live in a seismic area, or if the masonry is fairly old.

Always burn wood that's been down/dried at least one year. Spruce and birch produce the least amount of creosote. I also remove the 'china hat' off my stack in the winter, as it clogs easily with creosote; it goes back on in the spring to keep the rain out.

.

.

.

Comment: An observation on building insulation:
I built a house some years ago now and insulated far above then building stadards - R30 basement to ceiling or better . A house built at the same time next to mine used the standard 2X4 framing ( R12 ) and skimped - the builder/owner laughing at my effort and "expense" ... Well - I recovered the extra cost of insulating within the first winter heating season and had a comfortably warm house, no draughts or cold spots from basement floor to second storey cathedral ceiling ... while my neighbour complained about his heating bill and cold basement.

If I were to build today:
- R60 everywhere.
- Triple glazed windows.
- A separate 12VDC circuit for lighting and electronics - powered by cheap lead acid battery bank and solar. No $$ inverter complexities. AC cct. only for kitchen.
- No basement - we don't have one now and don't miss it. No risk of flooding.
- Propane cook stove, water heater, drier .... 
Of course a garage/workshop for my Corvette  .-)

Comment: Louis VII was king of France  in the 12th century. As a result of the parks on the outskirts, Paris has a very large percentage of green space. However, this is primarily used by and was intended for the use of Parisians.  What attracts tourists is central Paris, including its old central parks as well as its buildings, museums,  churches, ambience etc, as well as Versailles, not the parks on the outskirts.  Tourists don't much rent car and drive around the outskirts of Paris.

Comment: The devils is, as they say, in the minutia.

It's so easy to state principles. But what do you mean when you state them; and then what do I mean? Let's take the example of "property rights". To some, it means that I can do whatever I want on and with my property, and the community can go hang if they don't like it. No matter how my neighbours are affected.. 

Or what about religious garb? Some of it is historically designed to restrict women. But to ban it marginalizes those women even more. It forces them to choose between being sanctioned, or even harmed for not wearing it, and the law. "You can't access needed services because of what you wear. Sorry, the fact that you feel compelled to wear it is not my department. Go talk to the police or a lawyer, or something."

We always assume language is black and white. But interpretation of the law and its principles is a giant profitable industry. And we forget to take unintended consequences into account.

Comment: Anybody with basic knowledge of the cannabis industry understands that it cannot possible be compared to other non-regulated industries. From a basic commerce/business standpoint, Eugene cannabis businesses have no reciprocity with cities that have retained the 1,000 ft buffer, or with other legal states that have a residency requirement, which Oregon's legislature decided to throw out (so basically, they can come here but Eugene's retailers can't expand or move our businesses there). So right off the bat, that makes them fundamentally different from other retail businesses. Cannabis' closest comparison is liquor stores, which do have state-wide a distance regulation, but OLCC opted to leave this to municipalities because they didn't feel they had enough data yet to make statewide restrictions. Store locations will be regulated, but it might be too late for the small, local businesses by the time state-wide regulation comes around.

Comment: Tuners have a variety of uses, but your example actually does not necessitate one. A Harley-Davidson with an aftermarket muffler but an otherwise stock engine and fuel system does not need one. If the owner goes further and alters the header pipes or intake, then the fuel/air mixture needs to tuned richer to compensate for the increased airflow.

 You just stated that the owner opted to replace the factory exhaust. The Motor Company had nothing to with that individual, private citizen's decision. Then you state that it was "quite possibly" done by a dealership. I'm curious how far into that practice you've actually looked, because dealerships modify fuel systems at their own risk and are held responsible by the EPA for illegal modifications. They will offer to install exhaust and intake systems and then reflash the ECM to an EPA-compliant tune. Further, if asked to install parts that are not street-legal, they will require the customer to pick up the vehicle with a trailer.

"In a very basic sense, how can an employer not raise prices to compensate? " Um, if customers are not willing to pay higher prices? But most will, and some of the businesses that pay low wages, like restaurants, are selling middle-class luxuries that a lot of us can do without.

I don't know why he's having trouble finding good employees. Maybe because Oregonians aren't willing to pay for a decent educational system? In any case, it's a separate issue from the minimum wage.

Comment: Yes, you fundamentally misrepresented what he said. You said that Obama promised that "under his regime, the sea level would stop rising." That means that the oceans would no longer rise. They would hold steady or drop.

What he actually said (before he was president and after winning the primaries on June 4, 2008) was that the sea level rise would begin to slow. In other words, the rate of the rise would decrease but the level would still go up. 

There is data showing that he was right. The rate peaked in 2005 at 3.5 mm/year and stayed on a reasonably steady decline down to 2.6 mm/year in 2011 but now it seems to getting back to its higher rate.  

https://wattsupwiththat.com/2013/05/28/obama-was-rightthe-rise-of-the-oceans-began-to-slow/
